sen.j: 大物主（おおものぬし、大物主大神）は、日本神話に登場する神。
sen.e: Omononushi is a deity in Japanese mythology.
Omononushi is a deity in Japanese mythology.
Omononushi is a deity in Japanese mythology.

sen.j: 大神神社の祭神、倭大物主櫛甕魂命。
sen.e: Omononushi is enshrined in Omiwa-jinja Shrine and officially referred to as "Yamato no Omononushi kushi mika tama no mikoto".
Omononushi is enshrined in Omiwa-jinja Shrine and officially referred to as "Yamato no Omononushi kushi mika tama no mikoto."
The deity Omononushi is enshrined in Omiwa-jinja Shrine.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 『出雲国造神賀詞』では大物主櫛甕玉という。
sen.e: In "Izumo kokuso kamuyogoto" (ritual greetings by the highest priest of Izumo Taisha Shrine to the Emperor), he is mentioned as "Omononushi kushimikatama".
In "Izumo kokuso kamuyogoto" (ritual greetings by the highest priest of Izumo Taisha Shrine to the Emperor), he is mentioned as "Omononushi kushimikatama".
In "Izumo kokuso kamuyogoto" (ritual greetings by the highest priest of Izumo Taisha Shrine to the Emperor), he is mentioned as Omononushi kushimikatama.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。クォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: 大穴持（大国主）の和魂であるとする。
sen.e: The deity enshrined in Omiwa-jinja Shrine is considered to be the Onamochi's (Okuninushi's) Nigimitama (peaceful, calming aspect of a spirit).
sen.cmt: この文も主語がはっきりしませんが、上の流れと下の記述から、「大神神社の祭神」が主語であると考えて訳しています。
sen.e: The deity enshrined in Omiwa-jinja Shrine is considered to be the Onamochi's (Okuninushi's) Nigimitama (peaceful, calming aspect of a spirit).
The deity enshrined in Omiwa-jinja Shrine is considered to be the peaceful spirit of Onamochi (Okuninushi).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 別名 三輪明神。
sen.e: He is also called "Miwa-myojin".
He is also called "Miwa-myojin."
He is also called "Miwa-myojin."

sen.j: 古事記によれば、大国主とともに国造りを行っていた少彦名神が常世の国へ去った。
sen.e: According to Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters), Sukunabikona no kami, who had been working with Okuninushi to build this country, left for Tokoyo no kuni (the perpetual country), leaving him alone.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: According to Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters), Sukunabikona no kami, who had been working with Okuninushi to build this country, left for Tokoyo no kuni (the perpetual country), leaving him alone.

According to Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters), the deity Sukunabikona no kami, who had been working with the deity Okuninushi to build this country, left for Tokoyo (lit. "the normal world," though some texts hint that it is the afterworld) leaving Okuninushi alone.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。スペース補足、カンマの位置を変えました。

sen.j: 大国主神がこれからどうやってこの国を造って行けば良いのかと思い悩んでいた。
sen.e: Okuninushi was at loss what to do next to build the country.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: Okuninushi was at loss what to do next to build the country.
Okuninushi was at loss about what to do next to build the country.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: すると、海の向こうから光輝いてやってくる神様が表れ、大和国の三輪山に自分を祭るよう希望した。
sen.e: Then, he saw a shining deity coming from beyond the sea, and the deity wished him to enshrine him in Mt. Miwa in Yamato Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: Then, he saw a shining deity coming from beyond the sea, and the deity wanted Okuninushi to enshrine him in Mt. Miwa in Yamato Province.
Then, he saw a shining deity coming from beyond the sea and the deity wanted Okuninushi to enshrine him in Mt. Miwa in Yamato Province.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 大国主が「どなたですか？」と聞いた。
sen.e: "Who are you", asked Okuninushi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: "Who are you", asked Okuninushi.
Who are you,' asked Okuninushi.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合わせ"を'にコンマを'内に移動

sen.j: 「我は汝の幸魂（さきみたま）奇魂（くしみたま）なり」と答えたという。
sen.e: "I am your "Saki mitama" (soul that makes people happy by luck) and your "Kushi mitama" (soul that makes people happy by miracle), he answered.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: "I am your "Saki mitama" (soul that makes people happy by luck) and your "Kushi mitama" (a soul that makes people happy with miracles), he answered.
I am your Saki mitama (soul that makes people happy by luck) and your Kushi mitama (a soul that makes people happy with miracles),' he answered.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 日本書紀の一書では大国主神の別名としている。
sen.e: According to an opinion cited in Nihonshoki, Okuninushi no kami is also referred to as "Saki mitama" or "Kushi mitama".
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理ここでは、何を大国主神の別名としたのかが、書かれておらず、一応、幸魂、奇魂を大国主神の別名としていると理解し、訳しました。
sen.e: According to an opinion cited in Nihonshoki, Okuninushi no kami is also referred to as "Saki mitama" or "Kushi mitama."
According to an opinion cited in Nihonshoki, Okuninushi no kami is also referred to as Saki mitama or Kushi mitama.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 大神神社の由緒では、大国主神が自らの和魂（にきみたま）を大物主神として祀ったとある。
sen.e: The history of Omiwa-jinja Shrine says that Okuninushi no kami enshrined his own Nikiitama as Omononushi-no-mikoto.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: The history of Omiwa-jinja Shrine says that Okuninushi no kami enshrined his own Nikiitama as Omononushi-no-mikoto.
The history of Omiwa-jinja Shrine says that Okuninushi no kami enshrined his own Nikimitama as Omononushi-no-mikoto.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: ミシマノミゾクヒの娘のセヤダタラヒメ（勢夜陀多良比売）が美人であるという噂を耳にした大物主は、彼女に一目惚れした。
sen.e: Having heard people say that Seyadatarahime, a daughter of Mishima no mizokui, was a beauty, Omononushi who fell in love with her at a glance.
Having heard people say that Seyadatarahime, the daughter of Mishima no mizokui, was a beauty, Omononushi who fell in love with her at a glance.
Having heard people say that Seyadatarahime, the daughter of Mishima no mizokui, was a beauty, Omononushi who fell in love with her at first sight.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: セヤダタラヒメに何とか声をかけようと、大物主は赤い矢に姿を変えた。
sen.e: Wanting to talk to her somehow, he turned himself into an red arrow and waited.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: Wanting to talk to her somehow, he turned himself into an red arrow and waited.
Wanting to talk to her somehow, he turned himself into a red arrow and waited.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: セヤダタラヒメが用を足しに来る頃を見計らって川の上流から流れて行った。
sen.e: When he saw her coming to a river for a pee, he, an arrow, started to flow down the stream.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: When he saw her coming to a river to pee, he, the arrow, started to flow down the stream.
When he saw her coming to a river to relieve herself the arrow started to flow down the stream.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 彼女の下を流れていくときに、ほと（陰所）を突いた。
sen.e: When it came beneath her, it stuck in her private parts.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: When it came beneath her, it stuck into her private parts.
When it came beneath her, it stuck into her nether regions.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 彼女がその矢を自分の部屋に持ち帰ると大物主は元の姿に戻り、二人は結ばれた。
sen.e: When she brought the arrow back to her room, it turned itself back into Omononushi, and then they made love.
When she brought the arrow back to her room, it changed back into Omononushi, and then they made love.
When she brought the arrow back to her room, it changed back into Omononushi, and then they made love.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: こうして生れた子がヒメタタライスズヒメ（イスケヨリヒメ）で、後に神武天皇の后となった。
sen.e: This was how Himetataraisuzu hime (Isukeyori hime), the future empress of Emperor Jinm, came into being.
This was how Himetataraisuzu hime (Isukeyori hime), the future empress of Emperor Jinm, came into being.
This was how Himetataraisuzu hime (Isukeyori hime), the future empress of Emperor Jinmu, came into being.

sen.j: スエツミミ命の娘のイクタマヨリビメの前に突然立派な男が現われて、二人は結婚した。
sen.e: Suddenly, there appeared a handsome man in front of Ikutamayori bime, a daughter of Suetsumimi no mikoto, and they made love.
sen.cmt: ここで、話が全く変わっています。上との内容のつながりがありませんので、ご注意を。
sen.e: Suddenly, there appeared a handsome man in front of Ikutamayori bime, a daughter of Suetsumimi no mikoto, and they made love.
Suddenly, there appeared a handsome man in front of Ikutamayori bime, a daughter of Suetsumimi no mikoto, and they made love.

sen.j: しかしイクタマヨリビメはそれからすぐに身篭ってしまった。
sen.e: To her dismay, she soon became pregnant.
To her dismay, she soon became pregnant.
To her dismay, she soon became pregnant.

sen.j: 不審に思った父母が問い詰めた。
sen.e: Worrying about her, her parents questioned her about what had happened.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: Worrying about her, her parents questioned her about what had happened.
Worrying about her, her parents questioned her about what had happened.

sen.j: イクタマヨリビメは、名前も知らない立派な男が夜毎にやって来ることを告白した。
sen.e: At last, she confessed that she had a handsome man coming to her every night although she did not know who he was.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: At last, she confessed that she had a handsome man coming to her every night although she did not know who he was.
At last, she confessed that she had a handsome man coming to her every night although she did not know who he was.

sen.j: 父母はその男の正体を知りたいと思い、糸巻きに巻いた麻糸を針に通し、針をその男の衣の裾に通すように教えた。
sen.e: Anxious to know who he was, her parents told her to get a linen thread on a spool through a needle and to stick it to the hem of his garment.
Anxious to know who he was, her parents told her to get a linen thread on a spool through a needle and to attach it to the hem of his garment.
Anxious to know who he was, her parents told her to get a linen thread on a spool through a needle and to attach it to the hem of his garment.

sen.j: 翌朝、針につけた糸は戸の鍵穴から抜け出ており、糸をたどると三輪山の社まで続いていた。
sen.e: Next morning, they saw the tread going out through a key hole and extending all the way to a shrine in Mt. Miwa as they tracked it.
Next morning, peering through a keyhole, they saw the tread going out extending all the way to a shrine on Mt. Miwa as they tracked it.
Next morning, peering through a keyhole, they saw the tread going out extending all the way to a shrine on Mt. Miwa as they tracked it.

sen.j: 糸巻きには糸が3回りだけ残っていたので、「三輪」と呼ぶようになったという。
sen.e: As there was only three rolls ("miwa", literally "three rings") of thread left on the spool, the place where the other end of the tread was found got the name of "Miwa".
sen.cmt: 「三輪」と呼んだものが何かがわかりにくかったので調べてみると、どうやら地名のようです。そのように訳出しています。
sen.e: As there were only three rolls ("miwa," literally "three rings") of thread left on the spool, the place where the other end of the thread was found got the name of "Miwa."
As there were only three rolls ("miwa," literally "three rings") of thread left on the spool, the place where the other end of the thread was found got the name of 'Miwa.'

sen.j: また、崇神天皇に、自らをオオタタネコに祀らせるようにと告げた。
sen.e: On the other hand, Omononushi told Emperor Sujin to have Ootataneko enshrine him.
On the other hand, Omononushi told Emperor Sujin to have Ootataneko enshrine him.
On the other hand, Omononushi told Emperor Sujin to have Ootataneko enshrine him.

sen.j: これが現在の大神神社である。
sen.e: This is how today's Omiwa-jinja Shrine was built.
This is how today's Omiwa-jinja Shrine was built.
This is how today's Omiwa-jinja Shrine was built.

sen.j: 大物主はヘビ神であり水神または雷神としての性格を持っている。
sen.e: Omononushi has many characters; he is a Hebigami (god of snake), Suijin (god of water), and Raijin (god of lightning).
Omononushi has many characters; he is a Hebigami (god of snakes), Suijin (god of water), and Raijin (god of lightning).
Omononushi has many characters; he is a Hebigami (god of snakes), Suijin (god of water), and Raijin (god of lightning).

sen.j: 稲作豊穣、疫病除け、酒造り（醸造）などの神として篤い信仰を集めている。
sen.e: He has been worshipped by people who pray for good rice harvest, the warding off of evil, and the protection of the sake brewing business.
He has been worshipped by people who pray for good rice harvest, the warding off of evil, and the protection of the sake brewing business.
He has been worshipped by people who pray for good rice harvest, the warding off of evil, and the protection of the sake brewing business.

sen.j: また国の守護神である一方で、祟りなす強力な神ともされている。
sen.e: He is believed to be a guardian of this country, but at the same time, to have the power to curse people.
He is believed to be a guardian of this country, but at the same time, to have the power to curse people.
He is believed to be a guardian of this country, but at the same time, to have the power to curse people.

sen.j: 明治初年の廃仏毀釈の際、旧来の本尊に替わって大物主大神を祭神とした例が多い。
sen.e: In Haibutsukisyaku (the anti-Buddhism movement), that started in the first year of the Meiji period, many temples adopted Omononushi-no-mikoto as their enshrined deity, replacing their Honzon (the principle image of Buddha) that had been worshipped for a long time.

In Haibutsukisyaku (the anti-Buddhism movement), that started in the first year of the Meiji period, many temples adopted Omononushi-no-mikoto as their enshrined deity, replacing their Honzon (the principle image of Buddha) that had been worshipped for a long time.

In Haibutsukisyaku (the anti-Buddhism movement), that started in the first year of the Meiji period, many temples adopted Omononushi-no-mikoto as their enshrined deity, replacing their Honzon (the principle image of Buddha) that had been worshipped for a long time.

sen.j: 一例：香川県仲多度郡琴平町の金刀比羅宮。
sen.e: An example of this was Kotohira-gu Shrine in Kotohira Town, Nakatado District, Kagawa Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: An example of this was Kotohira-gu Shrine in Kotohira Town, Nakatado District, Kagawa Prefecture.
An example of this was Kotohira-gu Shrine in Kotohira-cho, Nakatado-gun, Kagawa Prefecture.

sen.j: 本来は寺院だったものを神社に変更してしまい、その際本尊としては十二神将の一人の宮毘羅大将だったものを大物主大神に変更している。
sen.e: Kotohira-gu, which had been a temple, became a Shinto shrine, replacing Kubira Taisho, one of Juni Shinsho (twelve heavenly generals of Yakushi Buddha), worshipped as the principle image, with Omononushi-no-mikoto.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: Kotohira-gu, which had been a temple, became a Shinto shrine, replacing Kubira Taisho, one of Juni Shinsho (twelve heavenly generals of Yakushi Buddha), worshipped as the principle image, with Omononushi-no-mikoto.

Kotohira-gu, which had been a temple, became a Shinto shrine, replacing Kubira Taisho, one of Juni Shinsho (twelve heavenly generals of Yakushi Buddha), worshipped as the principle image, with Omononushi no mikoto.

sen.j: しかし、明治の諸改革は王政復古をポリシーに掲げていたので、中世、近世のご本尊は古代の神社登録資料にも沿う形で行われた。
sen.e: However, many reforms carried out by the Meiji government, whose policy revolved around the restoration of imperial rule, conformed to the ancient records of registered Shinto shrines.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理
sen.e: However, many reforms carried out by the Meiji government, whose policy revolved around the restoration of imperial rule, conformed to the ancient records of registered Shinto shrines.
However, many reforms carried out by the Meiji government, whose policy revolved around the restoration of imperial rule, conformed to the ancient records of registered Shinto shrines.

sen.j: 必ずしも出雲神への変更が的外れでなかった場合が多い。
sen.e: In general, a shift from Buddha to Shinto deities of Izumo (the heartland of Japanese mythology) took place in a systematic way.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外処理ここの「的外れ」の意味ですが、「適当に」「根拠なく」という意味に解釈して訳しています。
sen.e: In general, a shift from Buddha to Shinto deities of Izumo (the heartland of Japanese mythology) took place in a systematic way.
In general, a shift from Buddha to Shinto deities of Izumo (the heartland of Japanese mythology) took place in a systematic way.
